2. Advantages of spin: First, there is the possibility of lower power dissipation in switching logic gates. In charge-based devices, such as metal oxide semiconductor field effect transistors, switching between logic 0 and logic 1 is accomplished by moving charges into and out of the transistor channel. 
3. Spin does not couple easily to stray electric fields (unless there is strong spin-orbit interaction in the host material). 
4. Spin is likely to be relatively immune to noise. 
5. Spin devices may be faster. 
6. If we do not have to move electrons around, we will not be limited by the transit time of charges. 
7. In 1994, we proposed a concrete scheme for realizing a classical universal logic gate (nand) using three spins placed in a weak magnetic field.

6. This is detrimental to the practical realization of quantum information processing using entanglement.
7. Surprisingly, some further studies indicated that ESD is not always the eventual fate of the qubit entanglement.
8. It was found that the entanglement can revive again after some time of ESD.
9. This revival entanglement plays a constructive role in quantum information protocols.
10. Even in some occasions, ESD does not happen at all, instead finite residual entanglement can be preserved in the long time limit.
11. This can be due to the structured environment and physically it results from the formation of a bound state between the qubit and its amplitude damping reservoir.

13. The entanglement does not go away, it is still there but just changes the location.
14. This is reminiscent of the work of Yonac et al.

18. However, it would be surprising if the identity is still valid in the presence of the decoherence, in which a non-equilibrium relaxation process is involved.
19. In this paper, we show that it is indeed true for such a system consisting of two qubits locally interacting with two amplitude-damping reservoirs.

<summary>Scientific research publications are abundant, making it challenging to select a high-quality work. The citation mechanism is a key factor in determining scientific credibility. The citation distribution of scientific publications follows a power-law form with an exponent of 0.8. The citation distribution of scientific publications is well studied and several network models have been developed to mimic its complex structure. The proposed model analyzes the time evolution of network structures and provides insights into the distribution of intra- and cross-links. The model is particularly useful for understanding the interplay between different research areas and the relationships between them.</summary>

Theoretical descriptions of hadron production at large transverse momentum ( @xmath2 ) in either hadronic or nuclear collisions at high energies are traditionally framed in a two-step process that involves first a hard scattering of partons, followed by the fragmentation of the scattered parton to the detected hadron. The first part is calculable in perturbation QCD, while the second part makes use of fragmentation functions that are determined phenomenologically. Such a production mechanism has recently been found to be inadequate for the production of particles at intermediate @xmath2 in heavy-ion collisions. Instead, it is the recombination of partons that is shown to be the more appropriate hadronization process, especially when the soft partons are involved. Although at extremely high @xmath2 fragmentation is still dominant, it is desirable to have a universal description that can be applied to any @xmath2 based on the same hadronization scheme. To achieve that goal, it is necessary that the fragmentation process can be treated as the result of recombination of shower partons in a jet. The main objective of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and to determine their distributions in order to represent the phenomenological fragmentation functions in terms of recombination. The subject matter of this work is primarily of interest only to high-energy nuclear collisions because hadronization in such processes is always in the environment of soft partons. Semi-hard shower partons initiated by a hard parton can either recombine among themselves or recombine with soft partons in the environment. In the former case, the fragmentation function is reproduced, and nothing new is achieved. It is in the latter case that a very new component emerges in heavy-ion collisions, one that has escaped theoretical attention thus far. It should be an important hadronization process in the intermediate @xmath2 region. Our main objective here is to quantify the properties of shower partons and to illustrate the importance of their recombination with thermal partons. The actual application of the shower parton distributions ( spd ) developed here to heavy-ion collisions will be considered elsewhere. The concept of shower partrons is not new, since attempts have been made to generate such partons in PQCD processes as far as is permitted by the validity of the procedure. Two notable examples of such attempts are the work of marchesini and webber and geiger. The need for efficient use of the scarce spectrum in wireless applications has led to significant interest in the analysis of cognitive radio systems. One possible scheme for the operation of the cognitive radio network is to allow secondary users to transmit concurrently on the same frequency band with primary users as long as the resulting interference power at the primary receivers is kept below the interference temperature limit. Note that interference to the primary users is caused by the broadcast nature of wireless transmissions, which allows the signals to be received by all users within the communication range. Note further that this broadcast nature also makes wireless communications vulnerable to eavesdropping. The problem of secure transmission in the presence of an eavesdropper was first studied from an information-theoretic perspective in Wyner's work, where he considered a wiretap channel model. In Wyner's result, the secrecy capacity is defined as the maximum achievable rate from the transmitter to the legitimate receiver, which can be attained while keeping the eavesdropper completely ignorant of the transmitted messages. Later, Wyner's result was extended to the Gaussian channel in his work. Recently, motivated by the importance of security in wireless applications, information-theoretic security has been investigated in fading multi-antenna and multiuser channels. For instance, cooperative relaying under secrecy constraints was studied in Pei et al.'s work. In this paper, we investigate the collaborative relay beamforming under secrecy constraints in the cognitive radio network. First, we characterize the secrecy rate of the amplify-and-forward (AF) cognitive relay channel. Then, we formulate the beamforming optimization as a quasiconvex optimization problem that can be solved through convex semidefinite programming (SDP). We propose two sub-optimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce the computational complexity. We consider a cognitive relay channel with a secondary user source, a primary user, a secondary user destination, an eavesdropper, and relays as depicted in the figure. We assume that there is no direct link between the primary user and the secondary user, and the relays work synchronously to perform beamforming by multiplying the signals to be transmitted with complex weights. We denote the channel fading coefficient between the primary user and the secondary user by p_s, the fading coefficient between the secondary user and the eavesdropper by p_e, the fading coefficient between the secondary user and the destination by p_d, and the fading coefficient between the secondary user and the relays by p_r. However, in order to quantize the Maxwell field and due to gauge freedom, a gauge fixing condition is necessary. The Lorenz gauge is usually used, which breaks the @xmath0 invariance. Since such a symmetry might lack physical meaning, its breaking does not bother many people. The purpose of the present paper is to demonstrate the benefits of keeping this fundamental symmetry when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS). The starting point is the following. A classical @xmath0-invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFSs, so why not maintain the @xmath0-invariance during the quantization process in a CFS? Doing so, a free field living in a CFS might behave like in a flat space and the corresponding Wightman two-point functions can be related to their Minkowskian counterparts. The work confirms this assertion in the special case of the Maxwell field in de Sitter space. In general, a new and simple two-point Wightman function is found and which has the same physical (gauge independent) content as the two-point function of Allen and Jacobson. This is because the faraday propagator is the same. The present work extends to general CFS and clarifies the quantum structure of the formalism developed in @xcite. We use the Dirac six-cone formalism and realize all CFSs as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in a six-dimensional Lorentzian space. The introduction of auxiliary fields and the use of the Gubla-Beler quantization scheme are necessary to deal with gauge freedom of the Maxwell field. Another important ingredient is the use of a well-suited coordinate system. This allows to get a Minkowskian form. The main result is a set of Wightman two-point functions for the Maxwell and auxiliary fields. This paper is organized as follows. 1. The study of short bursts, particularly those with high energy emission, has been a subject of interest in recent years, with the discovery of the high energy emission by the Fermi satellite in 2009.
2. The Fermi satellite's observations of grb 090510, a bright short burst with an emission detected from the kev to the gev range, have provided crucial data for understanding the properties of the source.
3. The Fermi satellite's data analysis, guided by the fireshell theory, has allowed for the identification of three distinct episodes in s - grbs: the p - grb, the prompt emission, and the gev emission.
4. The p - grb spectrum of grb 090510, spanning from 2009 to 2010, is best fitted by a comptonized component, interpreted as a convolution of thermal spectra originating in a dyadotorus.
5. The prompt emission of grb 090510, observed from 2009 to 2010, is characterized by a delayed onset, coinciding with the p - grb emission, and is associated with the onset of the gev emission.
6. The gev emission of grb 090510, observed from 2009 to 2010, is observed at the end of the p - grb emission and is initially concurrent with the prompt emission.
7. The sequence of events in grb 090510, including the p - grb, the prompt emission, and the gev emission, is one of the most intense ever observed in any grb, with a redshift of 6.4, consistent with the spectroscopically measured value of 0.6, and a spatially resolved structure of the prompt emission, typical of galactic halos where binary ns mergers are expected to migrate due to large natal kicks.

<summary>Organic Molecular Crystals: Emerging Applications in Nanoscale Devices</summary>

Organic molecular crystals, composed of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces, are emerging as excellent candidates for fabricating nanoscale devices. These have potential applications in electronics and optoelectronics, particularly in areas such as solar energy harvesting, surface photochemistry, organic electronics, and spintronics. The electronic structure of the interface between the organic and inorganic components plays a crucial role in determining the final device performance, and this is a challenging task, especially in the single-molecule limit. Upon adsorption on a substrate, the electron addition and removal energies of a molecule change value from that of their gas phase counterparts. This is expected since, when the molecule is physisorbed on a polarisable substrate, the removal (addition) of an electron from (to) the molecule gives rise to a polarisation of the substrate. The image charge accumulated on the substrate in the vicinity of the molecule alters the addition or removal energy of charge carriers from the molecule. A common way to calculate the addition and removal energies is to use a quasiparticle (qp) description. Within the qp picture, one ignores the effects of relaxation of molecular orbitals due to addition or removal of electrons and consequently takes the relative alignment of the metal fermi level, @xmath1 , with either the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital ( lumo ) and highest occupied molecular orbital ( homo ) of a molecule as removal energy. This effectively corresponds to associate the electron affinity and the ionization potential respectively to the lumo and homo of the molecule. The adequacy of the qp description then depends on the level of theory used to calculate the energy levels of the homo and lumo. If the theory of choice is density functional theory (dft), then a number of observations should be made. Firstly, it is important to note that except for the energy of the homo, which can be rigorously interpreted as the negative of the ionization potential, in general the kohn - sham orbitals can not be associated to qp energies. However, this is commonly done in practice and often the kohn - sham qp levels provide a good approximation to the true removal energies, in particular in the case of metals. Unfortunately, the situation is less encouraging with the local and semi-local approximations of the exchange and correlation functional, namely the local density approximation (lda) and the generalized gradient approximation (gga), performing rather poorly even for the homo level

1. Dwarf galaxies, particularly the Orion dwarf, are crucial for investigating the nature of dark matter (DM) in galaxies. Their kinematics are dominated by the DM component, down to small galactocentric radii, making them excellent candidates for DM halos.

2. Dwarf galaxies like the Orion dwarf provide a critical test of the NFW (N-body Dark Matter) profile, which is consistent with DM halos in actual DM halos around galaxies. The NFW profile arises from pure N-body DM simulations, with a core density core.

4. The present investigation examines the DM content of the Orion dwarf galaxy. This nearby system harbors an extended disk, providing an important test of the DM particle and evolution of DM halos.

The melting phase transition of two-dimensional (2D) systems has not lost its intensity over the past several decades. Recent developments in the fabrication of 2D materials have sought to clarify the details of the transition, with the Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Yang (KTHNY) picture as the most widely accepted theory. The KTHNY theory proposes that two separate, continuous transitions can be distinguished, with the solid transforming into a liquid in quasi-equilibrium steps by slow heating. During the first stage, the translational order vanishes, while in the second stage, the orientational order decays. All this is mediated by the unbinding of (i) dislocation pairs into individual dislocations and (ii) dislocations into point defects. The strength of this theory is its compatibility with the Mermin-Wagner theorem that forbids exact long-range positional order in 2D for a wide range of pair potentials at finite temperatures. The most criticized weakness of the theory is that it assumes a dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects, which is in contradiction with observations where the alignment and accumulation of dislocations into small angle domain walls was found. Since the birth of the KTHNY theory, investigations of its validity for systems with different pair interactions have been in focus. The examination of its validity for systems with dipole-dipole and debye-hckel interactions has shown that the phase transition is not first order but second order. The effect of the range of the potential on two-dimensional melting was studied in the 2D lennard-jones system for a wide range of Morse potentials. The observation of the hexatic phase is strongly linked with the thermodynamic equilibration of the systems. The necessary equilibration time, in turn, strongly depends on the measured quantity of interest. The velocity momenta have initial values very different from the expected maxwell-boltzmann equilibrium distribution. The velocity momenta approach the equilibrium value asymptotically with regular oscillations. The relaxation time can be characterized by a short relaxation time of the velocity distribution. The long-range decay of the pair-correlation and bond-angle correlation functions is also observed. The velocity momenta show initial values very different from the expected maxwell-boltzmann equilibrium distribution. The velocity momenta approach the equilibrium value asymptotically with regular oscillations. The configurational temperature is found to be significantly longer than the velocity distribution. According to quantum electrodynamics, quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources. In 1948, H. B. Casimir predicted that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation. The plates act as a cavity where only the electromagnetic modes with nodes on both walls can exist. The zero-point energy (per unit area) when the plates are kept at close distance is smaller than when the plates are at infinite separation. The plates thus attract each other to reduce the energy associated with the fluctuations of the electromagnetic field. The Casimir-Lifshitz force between isotropic dielectrics is receiving considerable attention in the modern literature. The theory has been verified in several high precision experiments, although the investigation has been mainly focused on the interaction between metallic surfaces in vacuum. Less precise measurements in liquids have been reported, and experimental evidence for repulsive van der Waals forces between dielectric surfaces in different fluids has also been reported. Finally, the Casimir-Lifshitz force might be a potentially relevant issue for the development of micro- and nanoelectromechanical systems.

1. The study of complex networks has notably increased in the last years with applications to various fields ranging from computer science to biology to social science.

The analysis of dynamic processes in complex networks is a significant research area with applications in social, biological, and technological systems. The spread of information in online social networks, the evolution of an epidemic outbreak in human contact networks, and the dynamics of cascading failures in the electrical grid are relevant examples of these processes. While major advances have been made in this field, most modeling and analysis techniques are specifically tailored to study static networks. However, empirical observations in social, biological, and financial networks illustrate how real-world networks are constantly evolving over time. Unfortunately, the effects of temporal structural variations in the dynamics of networked systems remain poorly understood. In this research direction, we find the seminal work by Gross et al. in @xcite, where a simple adaptive rewiring mechanism was proposed in the context of epidemic models. In this model, a susceptible node can cut edges connecting him to infected neighbors and form new links to any randomly selected susceptible nodes without structural constraint in the formation of new links. Despite its simplicity, this adaptation mechanism induces a complex bifurcation diagram including healthy, oscillatory, bistable, and endemic epidemic states. Several extensions of this work can be found in the literature, where the authors assume homogeneous infection and recovery rates in the network. Another model that is specially relevant to our work is the adaptive susceptible-infectious-susceptible (asis) model proposed in @xcite. In this model, edges in a given contact network can be temporarily removed in order to prevent the spread of the epidemic. An interesting feature of the asis model is that, in contrast with Gross model, it is able to account for arbitrary contact patterns, since links are constrained to be part of a given contact graph. Despite its modeling flexibility, analytical results for the asis model are based on the assumption of homogeneous contact patterns (i.e., the contact graph is complete) and homogeneous node and edge dynamics (i.e., nodes present the same infection and recovery rates, and edges share the same adaptation rates). In contrast, while controlling epidemic processes over static networks, we find a plethora of tools based on game theory or convex optimization. In this paper, we study adaptation mechanisms over arbitrary contact networks. In particular, we derive an explicit expression for a lower bound on the epidemic threshold of the asis model for arbitrary networks, as well as heterogeneous node and edge dynamics. <summary>AI3, a layered organic material, has attracted renewed interest due to its low-energy Dirac fermions under hydrous pressure. The material exhibits an average fermi velocity roughly one order of magnitude smaller than that of graphene, and its temperature-dependent carrier densities reveal significant differences between Dirac and massive carriers. The authors present magneto-transport measurements of AI3 under hydrostatic pressure, showing the existence of high mobility Dirac carriers and the presence of low mobility massive holes. The results suggest that AI3 can accommodate both Dirac and massive carriers, with the presence of massive holes driving the conduction properties at high magnetic fields and temperatures. The authors also discuss the implications of these findings for the understanding of strongly correlated Dirac fermions beyond graphene, and propose a theoretical framework for the study of strongly correlated Dirac fermions in AI3. The paper concludes with a discussion of the implications of these findings for the understanding of strongly correlated Dirac fermions in general.</summary>

Massive stars play a fundamental role in driving the energy flow and material cycles that influence the physical and chemical evolution of galaxies. Despite receiving much attention, their formation process remains enigmatic. Observations reveal that massive stars form via accretion (similar to low-mass stars) or through mergers of intermediate-mass stars. Advances in instrumentation have enabled sub-arcsecond resolution imaging at wavelengths less affected by large column densities of material that obscure regions at shorter wavelengths. Recent observations have uncovered the environment surrounding individual massive protostellar systems, from analysis of @xmath42.3 @xmath0 m co bandhead emission, @xcite have inferred keplerian disks very closely surrounding four massive young stellar objects, while interferometric, mm-continuum observations have found the mass-function of protostellar dust clumps lies close to a salpeter value down to clump radii of 2000 au. These high-resolution observations point toward an accretion formation scenario for massive stars. Further discrimination between the two competing models is possible by examining the properties, in particular the young stellar populations, of hot molecular cores. The mid-infrared (mir) window offers a powerful view of these regions. The large column densities of material process the stellar light to infrared wavelengths, and diffraction limited observations are readily obtained. Recent observations indicate that class II methanol masers exclusively trace regions of massive star formation, and are generally either not associated or offset from uchii regions. The spatial resolution of the observations (xmath68 xmath2) was, however, too low to resolve the sources inside the clumps. Details of the regions from literature are described in m05. We have since observed three of the m05 regions at high spatial resolution to uncover the embedded sources inside the cores at mir wavelengths. The data were obtained with michelle.

The optical pump-probe scheme is proposed to detect MFS in iron chains on the superconducting Pb surface. <summary>Understanding Phase Transitions: From Macroscopic to Microscopic</summary>

Phase transitions are fundamental phenomena in physics that occur at critical points where the behavior of a system changes dramatically. These transitions are often associated with symmetry breaking, where the underlying microscopic theory is no longer valid. The most common examples include the melting of a solid into a liquid, the transition from a solid to a gas, and the transition from a liquid to a gas. These transitions are crucial for understanding the behavior of materials and have wide-ranging applications in various fields, including materials science, condensed matter physics, and quantum mechanics.

Phase transitions are characterized by a sudden change in the macroscopic properties of a system, such as temperature, pressure, or concentration. The microscopic theory that describes the behavior of the system must be modified to account for the new macroscopic properties. This process is known as phase transition theory.

The most dramatic changes in macroscopic properties of a physical system occur at phase transitions, which often involve a symmetry breaking process. The theory of such phase transitions was formulated by Landau as a phenomenological model and later developed from microscopic principles using the renormalization group. One can identify phases by knowledge of an order parameter, which is zero in the disordered phase and nonzero in the ordered phase.

In the context of the ising model, the phase transition is found using principal component analysis (PCA) and variational autoencoders (VAE). PCA is used to identify the latent parameters that encode the order parameter, while VAE is used to reconstruct the input data from its latent representation. The reconstruction loss is minimized to find the best fit between the input and output data.

The variational autoencoder (VAE) is a powerful unsupervised learning algorithm that can handle nonlinear data. It is particularly useful for identifying phase transitions in models with continuous symmetries. The latent parameters of the VAE are used to represent the phase transition, and the reconstruction loss is used to identify the phase transition. The reconstruction loss is calculated as the mean squared error between the input and output data, and it changes drastically during a phase transition.

For example, consider the search of an item in an unsorted database containing @xmath1 elements. Classical computation requires @xmath1 steps to carry out the search. Grover's algorithm, however, requires only @xmath2 steps. Thus, Grover's algorithm represents a quadratic advantage over its classical counterpart. Grover's algorithm has been realized using many physical systems like nmr, superconducting qubits, and atom cavity qed. Superconducting qubit cavity qed is an attractive approach for quantum information processing due to its strong coupling limit in microwave cavity compared to atoms in cavity qed. Squids have attracted much attention among superconducting qubits due to their design flexibility, large-scale integration, and compatibility to conventional electronics. Recently, Carlo et al. demonstrated the implementation of two-qubit Grover and Deutsch-Jozsa algorithms using four-level squids in cavity qed. The goal of this work is to implement three-qubit Grover's algorithm using four-level squids in cavity qed. We consider a three-qubit phase gate, which reduces the number of quantum gates typically required for the realization of Grover's algorithm. Three-qubit Grover's algorithm is probabilistic, as compared to two-qubit Grover's algorithm. Therefore, to achieve high success probability, we have to implement basic searching iterations several times. The implementation of three-qubit Grover's search is much more complex as compared to two-qubit case. In our scheme, two lowest energy levels @xmath3 and @xmath4 of each squid represent logical states. The scheme is based on resonant, off-resonant interaction of cavity field with squid and application of resonant microwave pulses. Our scheme does not require adjustment of squid level spacing during the implementation of Grover's search iteration, thus, decoherence caused by the adjustment of level spacing is suppressed. We do not require identical coupling constants of each squid with the resonator and direct coupling between levels @xmath4 and @xmath6. Grover's iteration time becomes faster due to resonant and off-resonant interactions as compared to second order detuning or adiabatic passage. Grover's iterations based on three-qubit quantum phase gate employed here, considerably simplify the implementation as compared to conventional gate decomposition method. In the 1970s, many-body theory flourished, with much attention paid to the many-body effects on x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy spectra from deep core levels in metals. Related effects were singularities that appeared near edges in absorption and emission spectra. The cb (conduction-band electrons) can have many different effects on the x-ray photoelectron spectrum from the core level. If the excitation could be considered adiabatic, the screening of the core hole by the cb electrons would lead to a shift of the peak to higher kinetic energy (lower binding energy of the core level). Now the excitation is not adiabatic, the excitation is swift. The excitation frequency is large compared to the frequency components taking part in the screening of the core hole. This has the effect that the cb electrons are shaken up and are left in a nonequilibrium state. This is analogous to the case of the following case: assume that a cork is floating in a glass of water. If we remove the cork very slowly the water will be very quiet and without any ripples. If we on the other hand remove it very briskly the water will be in an upset state with many surface waves excited. In a metal, the water waves correspond to plasmons, collective excitations of the cb electrons. The shake-up effects will show up as plasmon replicas in the spectrum; the main peak will be at the adiabatic position; the first replica, a smaller copy of the main peak, will be at a shifted position to lower kinetic energy where the shift is equal to the plasma frequency; the second replica is even smaller and shifted with two plasma frequencies; this goes on until further peaks are absorbed by the background. The main peak corresponds to the system left in quasi equilibrium (fully equilibrium would demand that the core hole be filled by one of the electrons). The second to a state where one plasmon is excited, the third to a state where two plasmons are excited and so on. Since all plasmons do not have identical energies, the plasmon curve shows dispersion, the replicas are not completely identical smaller versions of the main peak. In a metal, single-particle excitations can take place. These electron-hole pair excitations form a continuum, starting from zero frequency and upwards. The phase-field method has become the method of choice for simulating microstructure formation during solidification. It owes its popularity to its algorithmic simplicity: the cumbersome problem of tracking moving solid-liquid interfaces or grain boundaries is avoided by describing the geometry in terms of one or several phase fields. The phase fields obey simple partial differential equations that can be easily coded by standard numerical methods. The foundations of the phase-field method and its application to solidification have been the subject of several recent review articles. Several topics are discussed where robust phase-field modelling tools are not yet available because some fundamental questions remain open. In sec. 2, the thin-interface limit of two-sided phase-field models is examined, and it is shown that the currently available approaches can not in general eliminate all effects linked to the finite interface thickness. In sec. 3, orientation-field models for polycrystalline solidification are discussed, and it is shown that the standard equation of motion usually written down for the orientation field is not appropriate for the evolution of coherent crystalline matter. Finally, in sec. 4, the inclusion of microscopic fluctuations in the phase-field equations is reviewed, and it is shown that the standard approach can not be used in a straightforward way to investigate the process of nucleation. The common point of these topics is that they pose challenges or limitations for straightforward computations. Indeed, a characteristic feature of the phase-field method is that its equations can often be written down following simple rules or intuition, but that their detailed properties ( which have to be known if quantitative simulations are desired ) become only apparent through a mathematical analysis that can be quite involved. Therefore, it is not always easy to perceive the limits of applicability of the method. It is hoped that the present contribution will be helpful to point out some pitfalls and to stimulate further discussions that will facilitate the solution of these issues. The precision and performance of phase-field models have been greatly enhanced in the last decade by a detailed control of their properties. Phase-field models are rooted in the mean-field description of spatially diffuse interfaces by order parameters. However, to be useful for simulating microstructure formation in solidification, phase-field models need to bridge the scale gap between the thickness of the physical solid-liquid interfaces and the typical scale of the microstructures. This is achieved by increasing the interface width in the model, sometimes by several orders of magnitude. The study of polymer loop formation has been extensively studied for several decades, with renewed attention due to its importance in biology. DNA loops play a crucial role in genetic expression, replication, and recombination. For example, in E. coli, the lac repressor (lac repressor) mediates loop formation, which is essential for repressive regulation of lac genes. The hairpin loop formation is an elementary step in protein folding, and the cell interior is an active and nonequilibrium medium. Single molecule experiment techniques provide detailed information on the DNA loop formation. Recently, the power spectrum of the fluctuating force exerted on cytoskeleton was measured to be an order of magnitude larger than that expected from thermal equilibrium condition. This indicates that the cell interior is an active and nonequilibrium medium. The advance of single molecule experiment techniques provides detailed information on the DNA loop formation. Finzi and Gelles observed laci-mediated DNA loop formation and dissociation by monitoring nano-scale brownian motion of the micron-sized particle attached to one end of the DNA. Gemmen studied effects of tension in the presence of two-site restriction enzymes which can cut the DNA upon binding on two sites simultaneously. They found that the cleavage activity decreases approximately 10-fold as the tension increases from 30 fn to 700 fn. They also found that the optimum loop size decreases with the tension, which is qualitatively in agreement with theoretical predictions. More recently, Chen et al. studied effects of tension in femtonewton range on the kinetics of laci-mediated DNA looping. They found that small tension of 100 fn scale on the substrate DNA can increase the looping time by more than two orders of magnitude. There is room for improvement in their approach, however, on the evaluation of the free energy that can be valid for short end-to-end distance of the chain as well as a description of detailed kinetic process using the mean first passage time approach. The recent discovery at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) of a resonance at 125 gev compatible with the expectations for the Higgs particle represents a major step towards understanding the origin of the mass of fundamental particles. This discovery is particularly relevant in models in which the Higgs field has nonminimal coupling to the general relativity sector, as invoked in various extensions of the standard model. Nonminimal coupling between the Higgs and spacetime curvature may be beneficial for having the Higgs responsible for inflation, and as a suppression mechanism for the contribution to dark energy expected from quantum fields at the LHC. The presence of a strong spacetime curvature deforms the vacuum expectation value of the Higgs field and therefore the mass of fundamental particles such as the electron. The analysis of the distance dependence of the newtonian gravitational constant has been discussed, and bounds on the gravitational interaction of the Higgs boson from the LHC experiments have been recently discussed. This mass shift is not present for protons and neutrons, due to the fact that their mass is primarily due to the gluonic fields which, being massless, are unaffected by the Higgs field. The paper presents a fast and efficient method to calculate the inclusive 2p-2h responses in the relativistic fermi gas model (rfg). The method, called the frozen nucleon approximation, is based on assuming that the momenta of the initial nucleons can be neglected for high enough values of the momentum transfer. This approximation is useful for computing the phase space function for two-particle emission in the range of momentum transfers of interest for neutrino experiments with accelerators. The method is validated by comparing the results with exact calculations and numerical simulations, and it is shown to be effective in computing the 2p-2h neutrino cross sections folded with the neutrino flux. The paper also discusses the limitations of the frozen approximation and its potential for future applications in Monte Carlo event generators.

The stequestime explorer and quantum equivalence principle space test (stequestime) is a medium-sized mission candidate for launch in 2022/2024 in the cosmic vision programme of the European Space Agency. The mission aims to study the cornerstones of Einstein's equivalence principle (eep) and push the limits of measurement accuracy by several orders of magnitude compared to what is currently achievable in ground-based experiments. The mott-hubbard model of interacting bosons on a lattice has been used to describe superfluid mott-insulator transitions in various systems, including Josephson arrays and granular superconductors. Recent experimental demonstrations of this transition have rekindled interest in the model and triggered a great deal of theoretical and experimental activity. Possible applications include the use of a mott state of bosonic atoms in an optical lattice as a starting point for creating controlled multiparticle entanglement as an essential ingredient for quantum computation. The mott-hubbard quantum phase transition is driven by the repulsive interaction of bosons on the same lattice site and the kinetic energy. Perturbation theory has been used to study this model analytically and numerically, with the gutzwiller mean-field ansatz and density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) being used to improve the wavefunction. The results show that the short-range correlations of the bosonic atoms in the optical lattice are important for determining the location of the insulator-superfluid transition. Summary 1: The paper discusses the classification and visualisation of homogeneous isotropic cosmologies in multi-scalar models with an arbitrary scalar potential. It introduces a geometrical method for the classification and visualisation of homogeneous isotropic cosmologies in multi-scalar models with an arbitrary scalar potential. The method involves two steps: first, the target space is augmented to a larger Lorentzian signature space, and then the logarithm of the scale factor is used as the time variable. The paper also discusses the non-flat cosmologies and their trajectories, showing that they are null geodesics in the augmented target space. The paper concludes by presenting a complete treatment of cosmological trajectories for any scalar potential and any spacetime dimension, for the special case of simple exponential potentials.

1. The term "stochastic resonance" was introduced in the early 1980s, specifically in the study of periodic advance of glaciers on Earth.
2. Stochastic resonance is the effect of nonmonotone dependence of the response of a system on the noise when this noise is added to a periodic input signal.
3. An extensive review on stochastic resonance and its presence in different fields of applications can be found in @xcite.
4. Following @xcite, as stochastic resonance we intend the phenomenon in which the transmission of a signal can be improved by the addition of noise.
5. The problem is to estimate a signal @xmath4 transmitted through a channel. This signal has to be detected by a receiver that can reveal signals louder than a threshold @xmath1.
6. If @xmath2 is bounded from above by @xmath1, the signal is not observable and the problem has not a solution.
7. But, if some noise @xmath3 is added to the signal, the perturbed signal @xmath4 may be observable and inference can be done on @xmath2.
8. Too few noise is not sufficient to give good estimates and too much noise deteriorates excessively the signal.
9. The optimal in some sense level of the noise will be called stochastic resonance in this framework.
10. Usually, the criterion applied to measure optimality of estimators are the shannon mutual information or the kullback divergence.
11. More recently, the fisher information quantity have been also proposed (see @xcite and @xcite).
12. Here we are concerned with the fisher information quantity.
13. It happens that this quantity, as a function of the noise, can be maximized for certain noise structures. If there is only one global maximum, the corresponding noise level is the value for which we have stochastic resonance, if several local maxima are present, the phenomenon is called stochastic multi-resonance.

4. The authors also observe a change in the angular pattern of the longitudinal thermal conductivity as the temperature increases, with the maximum amplitude observed at 3 kelvin.

8. The paper concludes by suggesting that the observed angular patterns can be used to compare the thermal transport properties of HTS samples with different doping levels, providing a new approach to understanding the behavior of quasiparticles in these materials.

The convection-diffusion model can be expressed mathematically as a semi-linear parabolic partial differential equation. Specifically, the initial value system of convection-diffusion equations in two dimensions is transformed into a system of first-order ordinary differential equations (ODEs) in time using the Spherical Shu-Robinson method. The proposed methods are found to be stable for both space and time convection-diffusion equations. The proposed methods are more accurate in comparison to existing schemes and agree well with the exact solutions.

Summary 1: The study explores the potential of submm and mm observations to identify and characterize the submm emission from complex galaxies, particularly those with radio counterparts. The authors discuss the challenges in detecting and identifying submm sources, including the limitations of current spectroscopic techniques and the need for improved data quality. They also highlight the importance of combining submm and mm observations to improve the detection and characterization of submm sources.
Summary 2: The study provides a robust sample of bright submm sources selected using scuba and mambo in the 8-mjy survey region. The authors use a dual-survey extraction technique to combine submm and mm maps of the lockman hole, resulting in a sample of 19 submm sources. The sample is compared to the spectroscopic redshift distribution determined by c05, which is inconsistent with the redshift distribution claimed by eales et al. The authors conclude that the submm emission likely originates from two central radio components, which are most likely at redshifts of 3.036 and 3.037. The authors also discuss the importance of combining submm and mm observations to improve the detection and characterization of submm sources.

1. Numerous techniques for forecasting electric energy consumption have been proposed in the last few decades, with the primary focus on load forecasting.
2. Consumers can benefit from the forecasted information to maximize satisfaction, and load forecasting has been used for system security purposes.
3. The economic reasons for load forecasting include historical trends, mean atmospheric temperature, mean relative humidity, population, GDP per capita, and weather information.
4. The time series approach, which uses trend analysis, is characterized by prediction inaccuracies and numerical instability.
5. The functional based approach, which models functional relationships between energy dependent variables and system loads, is more intelligent and widely used.
6. The soft computing based approach, which includes fuzzy logic, genetic algorithms, and artificial neural networks, is more intelligent and extensively used.
7. The ann approach, which uses a support vector regression model to predict energy consumption, is a more intelligent approach that is extensively used for demand side management.
8. The ann model, which uses a grey model, multiple regression model, and hybrid models, is a more intelligent approach that is extensively used for demand side management.

The axial anomaly represents a fundamental issue for understanding the basic aspects of quantum field theory. It has been extensively analyzed over the years, with the most formal approach being the path integral formalism. The axial anomaly can be derived using the dispersion relation method, and it has been shown to be related to the chiral limit and the infrared interpretation. The paper discusses the implications of the axial anomaly in the context of radiative decays of charged leptons, including the helicity changing processes. The paper also examines the implications of the axial anomaly in the context of gauge theories, such as QCD.

1. The nucleon in the low-energy regime is described by a unified chiral interaction that includes both the chiral interaction and the short-range interaction between constituent quarks.
2. The short-range interaction between constituent quarks is crucial for the nucleon spectrum, especially for the short-range repulsion in the nucleon system.
3. The chiral interaction between quarks is responsible for the short-range repulsion in the nucleon system, which also induces a short-range repulsion in the nucleon system.
4. The short-range repulsion in the nucleon system is related to the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry and is expected to be weak in the chiral constituent quark model.
5. The chiral interaction between quarks is essential for understanding the microscopically behavior of the nucleon, including the short-range repulsion and the hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy.

2. The calcium phosphate coating has the ability to form porous, semi-amorphous calcium phosphate films with controlled porosity and drug retention.

<summary>Summary:</summary>1. The present invention provides a fabricated implantable nerve guidance conduit (NGC) with integrated spiral structured porous sheets decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers. Such NGCs offer superior mechanical strength compared to NGCs in the prior art, along with integrated multiple channels, stable aligned fibrous layers, good inter-cell communication, and high surface/volume ratios within the NGCs. Chambers at the distal and proximal ends of the NGC provide additional space for fitting nerve stumps in order to reduce tension at the suture line between the NGC and the nerve stump. A dense outer fibrous tube on the outside of the spiral structured porous sheet can prevent the infiltration of scar tissue while the regeneration process takes place. One embodiment of the NGC of the present invention comprises a three-dimensional (3-D) spiral structured porous sheet having two chambers at the ends thereof. The spiral structure includes a highly porous PCL sheet, which may be formed as a spiral-wound sheet using known methods and decorated with surface channels on a surface of the spiral wound sheet, coated with a thin layer of aligned electrospun fibers on the surface channels, and a dense randomly-oriented fibrous tube on the outside of the NGC. Other bioresorbable materials known for use in the biomedical arts may be used in place of PCL for the sheet and fibers (e.g., collagen/PCL blends for the fibers). 

2. The NGC of the present invention is tunable in that its size can be varied in a controlled fashion depending on how it is to be used. The length and the outer diameter of the NGC are dependent on the size of the spiral-wound sheet. An NGC according to the present invention may have any length, thus enabling it to be used to repair long gaps in the axon for the repair or regeneration of peripheral nerves. 

3. The NGC of the present invention is tunable in that its size can be varied in a controlled fashion depending on how it is to be used. The length and the outer diameter of the NGC are dependent on the size of guidance spiral. An NGC according to the present invention may have any length, thus enabling it to be used to repair long gaps in the axon for the repair or regeneration of peripheral nerves.

<summary>Field of Invention</summary>
The invention relates to seat base support assemblies for furniture or the like, particularly for sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flexible steel bands. The invention finds particular advantage in sinuous band seat spring assemblies, and is discussed initially in that context.

<summary>Objectives</summary>
The primary objectives of the invention are to provide a new and improved rail connector for sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flexible steel bands, and to embody the salutary features of conventional helical spring connectors while retaining essentially none of the undesirable features thereof.

The invention also provides seat spring-enhancing connectors that combine the four essential seat-force-generators: torsion, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification, to produce the four most desired seat-performance characteristics: initial-drop, deep-drop, softness, and resilient uplift.

1. The present disclosure is directed to an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, including an anvil head assembly and an anvil shaft. The anvil head assembly includes an anvil plate and a cut ring assembly, while the anvil shaft includes a longitudinal body portion and flexible legs that define a longitudinal bore. The collet is positioned within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft to prevent damage to the anvil shaft and to secure the anvil head assembly to the anvil shaft. The collet is cylindrical and positioned to prevent damage to the flexible legs of the anvil shaft. The collet is also positioned to prevent damage to the anvil head assembly and to secure the anvil shaft to the trocar of the stapling device. The collet is formed from a suitable material, such as stainless steel or nylon, and is secured within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft in a position that does not interfere with outward flexing of the flexible legs of the anvil shaft. The collet is designed to perform the functions of the anvil assembly, including providing a stable connection to the trocar and preventing damage to the anvil shaft and anvil head assembly during coupling. The collet is particularly useful in endoscopic surgical procedures where the anvil assembly is grasped with a grasper and positioned to couple the trocar to the anvil shaft. The collet is also useful in other surgical procedures where the anvil assembly is coupled to the trocar. The collet is designed to be easily accessible and secure, making it suitable for use in various surgical applications.</summary>

The present invention provides a cardiac assist system that combines a muscle-powered cardiac assist system with a cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator. The system operates by delivering stimulation to a skeletal muscle grafted about the heart, sensing depolarizations of the patient's heart, measuring intervals between successive depolarizations, defining first and second interval ranges, determining the number of measured intervals falling within the first and second interval ranges, inhibiting stimulation to a skeletal muscle grafted about the heart upon sensing a depolarization within the first or second interval range, detecting the occurrence of a first type of arrhythmia when the number of measured intervals falling within the first interval range equals a first predetermined value, detecting the occurrence of a second type of arrhythmia when the number of measured intervals falling within the second interval range equals a second predetermined value, delivering a first type of arrhythmia therapy in response to the detection of the first arrhythmia, and delivering a second type of arrhythmia therapy in response to the detection of the second arrhythmia, the second type of arrhythmia therapy having a cardiac stimulation component and a skeletal muscle component. The invention also includes a method for detecting and treating a tachyarrhythmia, and a system for delivering cardioversion and defibrillation pulses. The invention is believed practicable in conjunction with any of the known anti-tachycardia pacing and cardioversion therapies, and it is believed most likely that the invention of the present application will be practiced in conjunction with a device in which the choice and order of delivered therapies is programmable by the physician, as in current cardiac pulse generators.

1. The present invention is a noninvasive esophageal displacement electrode that enables the distal end of the electrode to displace angularly within the stomach and subsequently be pulled back out of the esophagus, or alternatively, further angularly displaced upwardly into pressurized contact with the stomach wall to place the electrode in closer proximity to the heart ventricle.
2. The electrode includes a semi rigid plastic tube with an electrode on the distal end, which is crimped to form a hinge at the distal region of the tube. The tube is connected to a control mechanism that allows the user to cause the last couple of inches of the distal end of the tube to bend back on itself approximately 135 degrees from its original position.
3. The control mechanism is connected to the distal ends of the cords that extend from the proximal end of the pin to the control mechanism. The cords are connected to the proximal and distal ends of the pin, respectively, and extend proximally in the tube 10 out its proximal end 42 and into the control mechanism 20.
4. The control mechanism includes a sleeve that contains a slide that can be moved to the right to cause the pin 32 to move downwardly in the tube 10, thereby placing the electrode 14 in proximity to the upper stomach wall near the heart ventricle V. Further movement of the slide 52 will cause the distal portion of the tube 10 to deflect and place the electrode 14 in pressurized contact with the upper stomach wall, causing a bulge that places the electrode 14 closer to the ventricle V (FIG. 4).
5. The present invention provides a very convenient means of enabling an operator to place the esophageal stomach displacement electrode very close to the heart or other organ by means of a noninvasive procedure and thereby reduce the energy required to carry out the particular procedure such as pacing or defibrillation upon the patient.

<summary>Summary</summary>  
The present invention is a board game designed to simulate the ups and downs of life at a lake. It includes a lake theme with various elements such as lake areas, boats, dams, marinas, and marinas. Players roll dice to determine movement of tokens across the board, and if a player lands upon a lake area, boat dealership, dam, marina, lake cabin, marina, or marina, they must purchase it from the Bank. If a player lands upon a lake area that is already owned by another player, they must pay rent to the owner. Players can also erect lake cabins and marinas, which may be used for recreational activities. The game ends when all but one player is bankrupt, and the remaining player is declared the winner.

<summary>Summary:</summary>1. The present invention employs Radial Reflection Diffraction Tomography (RRDT) to reconstruct images of surrounding media, including vascular plaques and materials, using a flexible substrate with multiple transmitting and receiving elements.

5. The RRDT method can be used for non-destructive evaluation in applications other than intravascular RRDT imaging.

8. The method can be combined with elastography for further insight into elastic properties and plaque composition.
9. The method can be utilized for non-destructive characterization in applications other than intravascular RRDT imaging.

The present invention describes a biological oil composition, formulations comprising the oil composition, and the use of the oil composition in dietary supplements, functional foods and pharmaceutical products for the prevention or treatment of cardiovascular disease. The oil composition of the present invention differs from typical fish oil and krill oil in both gross chemical composition and fatty acid content. Despite its high wax-ester content, the oil composition of the present invention is a low-viscous and completely free-flowing liquid at room temperature. The copepod oil of the present invention has a markedly different biological effects than a concentrated preparation of EPA and DHA used in the same concentration as in the copepod oil. The copepod oil of the present invention prevents the formation of atherosclerotic plaques and is useful in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. The copepod oil of the present invention also has an effect on the total blood cholesterol level and is useful in the prevention and treatment of hypercholesterolaemia and elevated blood cholesterol levels. The biological oil composition of the present invention comprises from 20% to 75% by weight of wax esters, preferably 50% to 100% by weight of wax esters, and more preferably 70% to 100% by weight of wax esters. The copepod oil of the present invention comprises from 5% to 20% by weight of SDA, and from 3% to 15% by weight of EPA and 2% to 10% by weight of DHA. The copepod oil of the present invention further comprises 1000-4000 ppm of astaxanthin, mainly in esterified form. The present invention provides a dietary supplement formulation comprising an oil composition as described above. The present invention also provides a functional food formulation comprising an oil composition as described above. <summary>Summary</summary>  
1. Polyelectrolyte complexes show properties that meet the profile of requirements for biocompatible polymers, allowing for the incorporation of active substances into microparticles with specific effects on biodistribution, bioavailability, and absorption.
2. Microparticles composed of polyelectrolyte complexes can be prepared in average particle sizes from a few nanometers to a few hundred micrometers, and they can be in the form of emulsions or not. The size distribution can be adjusted by stirring speed, drop rate, nozzle diameter, pH, and the choice of the polyelectrolyte partners.
3. Polyelectrolyte complexes can be converted into microparticulate forms by either entrapment, absorption, precipitation, or incorporation of active substances. The incorporation of active substances can be carried out in at least four ways: by entrapment, absorption, precipitation, or incorporation.
4. Polyelectrolyte complexes are suitable for preparing pharmaceutical compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes and active substances, where the consistency properties can be varied and specific adjustments can be made on the other hand. They can be used for various therapeutic and diagnostic applications, such as cytostatic agents, contrast agents, and wound ointment preparations.
5. Polyelectrolyte complexes are also suitable for preparing air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis, and they can be used as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis.

The application described is a reflectance measuring apparatus designed to measure the reflectance of the skin. The apparatus comprises a probe with an aperture for light transmission, a flexible connection for fiber optics, and a measuring device with light emitting and receiving means. The reflectance measurement is performed by comparing the specular reflection and diffuse reflection values. The apparatus is adaptable to different skin surface sizes and can be used for various skin conditions. The measurement is performed in a miniaturized form, allowing it to be carried out on reduced surfaces and on areas less than 1 cm². The apparatus is easy to handle and requires no higher positioning accuracy. The correction of variations in light intensity is achieved using a circuit for regulating the source of light. The reflectance is calculated from the measured values of specular reflection and diffuse reflection, and the results are displayed as a mean value. The reflectance is calibrated using a matt surface of reference and a calibrated mirror. The results are recorded in a computer file containing other information about the patient's skin condition, examination date, and special conditions. The recorded information can be edited on paper via the printer. The final reflectance value is recorded in a file containing other information about the patient's skin condition, examination date, and special conditions. The recorded information can be edited on paper via the printer.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

The invention provides a dental cleaning and massaging apparatus that includes a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members. The upper channel member is designed to fit over the upper teeth and snugly against the upper gum, while the lower channel member is designed to fit over the lower teeth and snugly against the lower gum. The apparatus includes a first or outer membrane that extends from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member. The second or inner membrane extends from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member. The apparatus also includes bite blocks located in both the upper and lower channel members, which are used for massaging the gums. The apparatus also includes a hose or tube that connects the lower channel member to the upper channel member, and a coupler that connects the upper and lower channel members. The apparatus also includes a control box that provides air pulses and water or air pulses alone or water alone, and a remote control device that allows the user to operate the apparatus. The apparatus operates by providing air pulses to the bite blocks and air-sacks, which then massage the gums and clean the teeth. The apparatus also includes a source of water and cleaning fluid that can be used to clean and lubricate the gums during the massaging action. The invention can be operated with either air alone or cleaning fluid alone, and the user can switch between the two modes of operation using a remote control device.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

Pelvic organ prolapse (POP) is a common female problem that can have a profound impact on a woman's quality of life. The organs in the pelvic cavity, uterus, vagina, bladder and rectum, are held in place by a web of muscles and connective tissues that act much like a hammock. When these muscles and tissues become weakened or damaged, one or more of the pelvic organs shift out of normal position and literally "fall" into the vagina. 

Pelvic organ prolapse surgical reconstruction is performed through the vagina. During the procedure, the surgeon repositions the prolapsed organs, securing them to surrounding tissues and ligaments, and may use a synthetic non-absorbable polypropylene mesh implant. However, the prior art surgical procedures penetrate the patient from several directions. 

The present invention addresses this issue by providing a reliable anchoring of the mesh implant. The invention includes a needle for surgical threading of a strap of the implant through a tissue, the needle comprising a trap for trapping the strap to the needle, while the needle may be at the accessible side of the tissue; a tip for threading the trapped strap from the accessible side to the opposing side; and a mechanism for releasing the trap, the mechanism driven from the accessible side of the tissue, thereby allowing return of the tip to the accessible side of the tissue while abandoning the strap at the threaded point, thus performing threading from the accessible side of the tissue.

     - Setting the fuzzy inference rule R N  for the selected feature F N  to be:

       - applying a defuzzification procedure using Y N  at phases φ N  and weights W N  to determine the instantaneous phase φ.

The invention also includes a rigid insulating sleeve extending from the plug end of the instrument, with the sleeve extending from the plug end to the distal end of the tool, including the working tip electrode. 1. The invention provides a magnetic resonance imaging apparatus that allows high-contrast exposures in a short time, even for larger body segments.  
2. The apparatus includes a magnet with at least one patient receptacle and at least one support plate, as well as a predetermined number of transmit and/or receive coils. At least in two predetermined exposure positions, an exposure respectively takes place using predetermined adjustment parameters. The required adjustment parameters are determined in a preceding adjustment process and executed in a subsequent exposure process.  
3. The adjustment parameters are not determined immediately before each individual exposure, but rather in an adjustment process that precedes the exposure process. Only after the determination of the required adjustment parameters are the exposures carried out, in a separate imaging exposure process.  
4. The invention is suitable for a large number of different forms of magnetic resonance imaging apparatuses.  
5. The magnet can be fashioned as a cylindrical magnet or as a horseshoe magnet.  
6. The patient receptacle is fashioned as a patient tube.  
7. The transmit coils can be connected to a generator by means of a changeover switch and supplied with current via a transmit amplifier and a matching element.  
8. The receive coils can be connected to a receiver by means of a changeover switch and supplied with signals via a matching element and a receive amplifier.  
9. The configuration of the transmit coils and the receive coils is supplied to an adjustment unit as inputs.  
10. The adjustment unit processes the inputs and outputs corresponding control signals to the generator, transmit amplifier, matching elements, receive amplifier, receiver, and shim coil system.  
11. The inputs and outputs are stored in a memory until the conclusion of the examination.  
12. The invention allows high-contrast exposures without the need to omit an adjustment.

1. The present invention provides a releasable fastener for an album, comprising front and back covers and removable pages between the covers, the fastener having a pair of strap anchors, one adapted to be attached to the front cover and the other to the back cover, a strap extending between the anchor and the strap anchor, and means for providing a releasable connection between the strap and each of the strap anchors to enable insertion and removal of pages at the front and back of the album, the releasable connection permitting adjustment of the effective length of the strap between the anchors to accommodate a variable thickness of the album.

2. The strap anchors are of variable length which can be adjusted within predetermined limits to suit the number of pages within the album. To permit replacement or insertion of pages, one or other of the screws is removed to permit removal of the front or the back cover and possibly some of the album pages at the front or back while the other screw remains in position to retain the remainder of the album pages in alignment. This screw-type fastening system has been in use for many years but is not particularly convenient to use as it can be quite difficult to align the male and female screws while maintaining alignment of the pages particularly when adding album sheets to increase the size of the album.

<summary>Summary of the Present Invention</summary>

1. The present invention is a sulky comprising two wheels, individually fastened, but located along the same rotational axis, to a common frame provided with a driver's seat and shafts leading towards the draught animal.
2. The sulky is designed to be lightweight, easy-running, and strong to endure specific strain during exercise and competitions.
3. To achieve a stiff and stable structure while keeping the weight low, the sulky is manufactured using welded steel pipes, which are unsuitable for aluminium due to poor strength qualities.
4. The sulky is assembled by a user, requiring only a small space during storage and transportation, with components easily dispatched in a flat package.
5. The sulky is built up from inexpensive semi-produced components, such as casted elements and extruded profiles, with a design that is well suited for box packaging and DIY kits.
6. The sulky is designed to be colored by applying color tapes, which leads to an inexpensive and individual color display system for end users.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

1. The present invention addresses the problem of eliminating air or gas bubbles in rotating water feeds, particularly in water-cooled generators, by providing a bypass arrangement that automatically removes or reduces these bubbles to a tolerable extent.
2. The invention is particularly useful in connection with water-cooled generators that typically have coaxial feed and discharge ducts.
3. Prior art solutions for eliminating air bubbles in rotating water feeds often involve complex engineering designs and require considerable engineering effort.
4. The present invention provides a simple and effective solution by utilizing the pressure gradient between the inflow and outflow for automatic operation of the ventilation system.
5. The bypass arrangement in the invention is designed to be radially arranged, which allows for a relatively simple and efficient design.
6. The bypass is structured to include means for increasing the hydrodynamic resistance of flow through the bypass, enabling adequate pressure drop over a short distance with low resistance to flow.
7. The various features of novelty of the invention are pointed out with particularity in the claims annexed to and forming a part of this disclosure.
8. The invention is particularly useful in connection with water-cooled generators that typically have coaxial feed and discharge ducts.

1. The invention addresses the problem of decreasing the force peak (break-away peak) during a crash, thereby achieving a simple and cost-effective yet functional implementation.
2. This is achieved through a steering column with elastic prestress on at least one bending wire or strip.
3. The jacket unit is prestressed with respect to the retaining part in the displacement direction parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the vehicle front.
4. This prestress acts on the break-away connection between the jacket unit and the retaining part.
5. The force required in the event of a crash to release the break-away connection is decreased, since the elastic reset force of the at least one bending wire or strip is added to the force exerted, in particular through the secondary collision of the driver with the steering wheel, parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the vehicle front.
6. The force peak during the breaking away of the jacket unit from the retaining part (=break-away peak) can be decreased or entirely avoided.
7. The invention provides an adjustable steering column that is also adjustable in length.
8. The steering column is preferably implemented such that it is adjustable in length.
9. An advantageous embodiment of the invention provides that the retaining part is formed by a part of the securement device.
10. The retaining part in the closed state of the securement device is herein in engagement with a securement part which is secured in position with respect to the bracket unit such that it is nondisplaceable in the direction of the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft. Through this engagement between the securement part and the retaining part, at least a portion of the securement force is applied securing, in the closed state of the securement device, the jacket unit against a displacement parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft. In the opened state of the securement device, the retaining part and the securement part are out of engagement. However, the energy absorption device for enabling the energy absorbing dislocation of the jacket unit in the event of a crash is integrated into the securement device. In this embodiment of the invention, the vehicle-stationary mounting of the bracket unit can be provided. A further energy absorbing dislocateability between the bracket unit and a mounting part, displaceably supporting this bracket unit parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft and mounted stationarily on the vehicle, can consequently be omitted.

<summary>1. The present invention provides a process for mounting flat, uncontoured glass panels in curved window bays of vehicles, including the steps of placing a flat glass panel within a curved window bay, securing the panel along the edge of the bay, and applying adhesive sealant to the panel to conform to the curved window opening.</summary>

<summary>Summary:</summary>1. The packaging machine of the present disclosure is designed with a simpler, more compact design, providing a robust and independent transfer mechanism for tool members, which is independent of high wear components like belts. This design is advantageous for differentiating between work stations and facilitating precise packaging processes. 2. The packaging machine of the present disclosure includes two work stations on different vertical levels, allowing for more closely spaced work stations in the horizontal direction. This facilitates the adaptation of the packaging machine to varying conditions, such as different types of packaging materials or package shapes. 3. The packaging machine of the present disclosure features a rotating shaft arranged in the production direction, which is connected to a transfer mechanism for converting the rotational movement into a lifting movement of the tool members. This transfer mechanism is robust and independent of high wear components, such as belts, and can be implemented with a wear-reducing element to reduce wear-dependent loads on the transfer mechanism.

<summary>Summary</summary>  
1. The invention relates to disposable finishing articles that include a drive member permanently affixed to a rotatable spindle of a power tool, and a mounting hub constructed in such a manner that the grinding wheel is securely mounted on the spindle without the use of adhesives.
2. The invention provides a disposable finishing article drive member assembly that includes a backing flange with a central opening for engaging the grinding wheel, a pressure cap for securing the backing flange and the grinding wheel, and a retaining nut for securing the backing flange and the pressure cap to the spindle.
3. The invention utilizes a gripping rib on the backing flange to provide a non-removable clamping force between the backing flange and the grinding wheel, and a pressure cap to provide a non-removable clamping force between the backing flange and the drive member.
4. The invention includes a retainer nut that engages the backing flange and the pressure cap, and a pressure cap that snaps into locking engagement with the backing flange and the pressure cap.
5. The invention utilizes a gripping rib on the pressure cap to provide a non-removable clamping force between the pressure cap and the backing flange, and a gripping rib on the backing flange to provide a non-removable clamping force between the backing flange and the grinding wheel.
6. The invention includes a retaining nut that engages the backing flange and the pressure cap, and a pressure cap that snaps into locking engagement with the backing flange and the pressure cap.
7. The invention utilizes a gripping rib on the pressure cap to provide a non-removable clamping force between the pressure cap and the backing flange, and a gripping rib on the backing flange to provide a non-removable clamping force between the backing flange and the grinding wheel.

<summary>Summary of the Invention</summary>

1. The invention relates to power and free conveyor systems, particularly focusing on power and free conveyor systems where carriers are moved along predetermined paths by engaging conveyors.
2. The invention includes a third dog that is provided in longitudinally spaced relation to the first and second dogs and is normally urged to an operative carrier pushing position but is held by the track out of operative position. The second and third dogs include cam projections thereon that engage portions of the track which hold the second and third dogs out of operative position.
3. The invention provides selective transfer of carriers across short or long distances by selectively operable second and third dogs, allowing for transfer of carriers from one predetermined path to another.
4. The invention accommodates various systems where the transfer varies between short and long distances, such as from a faster to a slower conveyor or between conveyors moving at the same speed.
5. The invention can be operated by moving the dogs upwardly simultaneously or sequentially, allowing for minimizing the number of pushers on the conveyor chain.
6. The invention can be used for short and long distances, accommodating different transfer configurations, and providing selective transfer across short and long distances.
